tn.text: These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
In this phrase "his hands" represents Ishbosheth. AT: "Ishbosheth became weak" or "Ishbosheth lost all strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Now Saul's son had two men ... this very time
tn.text: This introduces the men Baanah and Rechab in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

tn.ref: for Beeroth is also considered part of Benjamin, and the Beerothites fled to Gittaim and have been living there until this very time
tn.text: Here the author provides background information about Beeroth for the reader. The area of Beeroth was part of the land that belonged to the tribe of Benjamin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This verse pauses the main story to provide background information about Mephibosheth, a descendent of Saul through Jonathan instead of through Ishbosheth. Mephibosheth will become an important character later in the book. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This phrase means "unable to walk."
This was the age of Jonathan's son at the time of his father's death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: the news about Saul and Jonathan
tn.text: This refers to the news about their death.
This is a woman or girl who is hired to care for young children.
This explains how Mephibosheth was injured so he was unable to walk.
This is the name of Jonathan's young son, the grandson of Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The story returns to the actions of Rechab and Baanah who were introduced in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:04:01|4:2]].
the middle of the day, the part of the day when it is the hottest
"cleaning chaff from wheat"
This idiom means "was trying to kill you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is one of the strongest oaths David could swear, as Yahweh is the witness. AT: "I swear on the life of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "life" refers to David himself. AT: "who rescued me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: How much more ... should I not now require his blood from your hand, and remove you from the earth?
tn.text: This question is used to show that the men had committed an especially serious crime. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You are even more guilty! It is my duty to require his blood from your hand and to remove you from the earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: require his blood from your hand
tn.text: The phrase "his blood" represents the life of Ishbosheth. Here "from your hand" represents Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, introduced in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:04:05|4:5]]. AT: "hold you responsible for the death of Ishbosheth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: cut off their hands and feet and hung them up
tn.text: These were symbolic actions to show contempt for the men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: they took the head of Ishbosheth and buried it in the grave
tn.text: This was a symbolic act to honor Ishbosheth. This could be stated explicitly. AT: "they honored Ishbosheth by burying his head in the grave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
